Lawrenceville (also known regionally as "Limerick") was laid out in 1816, by Thomas Gwynne, on land he owned 1.5 miles (2.4 km) northwest of where Lafayette is located today.
In 1816, Angus Ross opened Lawrenceville's first and only tavern.
The Lawrenceville Post Office was established on July 2, 1825.

data.event: By 1915, the original community was nothing more than pasture land, with no signs left to indicate there was ever a community.
Lafayette was laid out on October 1, 1834, by William Minter, and named in honor of Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette.

event.title: December 31, 1836, the Lawenceville Post Office was moved

data.event: On December 31, 1836, the Lawenceville Post Office was moved to Lafayette, and renamed Lafayette Post Office, with John Minter as the first postmaster of the new branch.
As of 1875, the community contained one drug store, one dry goods and grocery store, and one blacksmith shop.
The post office was discontinued on December 31, 1905, with mail service going through the London branch.
As of 1915, the community contained three general stores and one blacksmith shop.
